data.title: Why Billy Porter, Jharrel Jerome and RuPaulâ€™s Emmy wins made for a historic night
data.meta_description: "Once again, we watch history unfold," Emmy presenter Kerry Washington said with a huge smile as she announced that Billy Porter of FX's "Pose" had won for lead actor in a drama series.
data.text:
â€œOnce again, we watch history unfold,â€ Emmy presenter Kerry Washington said with a huge smile as she announced that Billy Porter of FXâ€™s â€œPoseâ€ had won for lead actor in a drama series.

It capped a night of historic wins for black men at TVâ€™s flagship awards. Besides Porter, Jharrel Jerome of Netflixâ€™s limited series â€œWhen They See Usâ€ and RuPaul of the reality competition series â€œRuPaulâ€™s Drag Raceâ€ scored major wins, sparking some of the eveningâ€™s most enthusiastic applause from the audience at the Microsoft Theater.

Porterâ€™s win took on added significance as he became the first openly gay black man to be named lead actor in a drama series for his role as the flamboyant ballroom emcee Pray Tell. The actor triumphed over a formidable field of performers, including past winner Sterling K. Brown of â€œThis Is Us.â€

The former â€œKinky Bootsâ€ star was ecstatic as he took the stage. Clad in a large flowing hat and sparkling black suit, Porter was as exuberant as his outfit.

â€œThe category is love, yâ€™all,â€ Porter exclaimed. â€œI am so overwhelmed and I am so overjoyed to have lived long enough to see this day. James Baldwin said, â€˜It took many years of vomiting up all the filth I had been taught about myself and halfway believe before I could walk around this earth like I had the right to be here.â€™ I have the right, you have the right, we all have the right!â€

â€œPoseâ€ explores the subculture of the LGBTQ ballroom scene in late 1980s and early 1990s New York, as well as of the lives of the people in that community.

Porter added, â€œWe as artists are the people who get to change the molecular structure of the hearts and minds of the people who live on this planet. Please donâ€™t ever stop doing that. Please donâ€™t ever stop telling the truth.â€

Jerome received one of the most rousing receptions of the evening when he won for lead actor in a limited series for â€œWhen They See Us,â€ which examines the case of the Central Park Five, five black and Latino Harlem adolescents who were wrongfully convicted of raping and beating a white female jogger in 1989. The 21-year-old actor became the youngest to win in the category for his portrayal of Korey Wise, who at 16 was the oldest of those charged. Wise is now a criminal justice reform advocate.

Jeromeâ€™s win was the sole victory of the night for the Netflix series.

As he took the stage, Jerome at first seemed overwhelmed. â€œI feel like I should just be in the Bronx right now, chilling, waiting for my momâ€™s cooking or something,â€ he finally said. â€œBut Iâ€™m here in front of my inspirations, in front of people Iâ€™m so motivated by. The reason Iâ€™m here is because of actors I was in the category with.â€

One of his competitors in the category was his â€œMoonlightâ€ costar Mahershala Ali, who was nominated for HBOâ€™s â€œTrue Detective.â€ In an interview just a few hours after he learned of his nomination in July, Jerome said, â€œIâ€™m so honored to be nominated with Mahershala. He was such an inspiration to me, always inspiring me to do better.â€

Jerome gave thanks to â€œmy beautiful mother, whoâ€™s with me today â€” I couldnâ€™t do it without her,â€ and his father, before thanking Netflix and the projectâ€™s creator, Ava DuVernay: â€œThank you for giving me this opportunity.â€

He saved his final thanks for the true-life subjects of the series, many of whom were in the audience. â€œThis is for the men who we know as the Exonerated Five. Thank you so much, itâ€™s a blessing.â€ Many in the group raised their fists in triumph.â€

Backstage, Jerome was asked about black actors often being awarded for portraying characters in pain. â€œYouâ€™re absolutely right, with `â€™Moonlight,â€™ â€˜12 Years a Slave.â€™ Unfortunately, I think our strongest stories are the stories of pain, considering thatâ€™s what we go through on a daily basis.â€

â€œRuPaulâ€™s Drag Race,â€ the VH1 reality show that pits drag queens against each other, won for competition series. The series also won last year for reality-competition series. RuPaul won last week at the Creative Emmys for competition series host.

There were also some significant disappointments for nominees of color, including Sandra Oh of â€œKilling Eveâ€ who came up short for the second consecutive year in her quest to become the first woman of Asian descent to win lead actress in a drama. Oh lost out to her â€œKilling Eveâ€ co-star Jodie Comer.

After the show, Porter addressed an awards show moment that picked up steam on Twitter â€” as RuPaul gave his speech after winning competition series for â€œRuPaulâ€™s Drag Race,â€ a camera pan caught Porter seemingly looking less than enthusiastic. Porter said that wasnâ€™t his intention.

â€œThereâ€™s never a side eye coming from me, thereâ€™s never anything negative coming from me. Youâ€™re never going to get it from me,â€ he said. â€œRuPaul is a friend of mine, I am so proud of him. I stand on his shoulders. He paved the way for me, so thereâ€™s never a side eye about that.â€
